data.title: Events in History on May 1
data.meta_description: Important events in history for the 1st of May. See what historic, important and momentous events in history happened on May 1.
data.text:
Events 1 - 200 of 254

Roman Emperors Retire

Diocletian and Maximian retire from the office of Roman Emperor

Supernova observed by Chinese and Egyptians in constellation Lupus

Bishop Bernold flees St Pieterskerk for Utrecht, Netherlands

Albert I, King of Germany, is assassinated by his nephew John of Swabia [the Parricide], for cutting John out of his right to inherit

Wars of Scottish Independence end: Treaty of Edinburgh-Northampton - the Kingdom of England recognises the Kingdom of Scotland as an independent state.

Ekiho exorcises the Zen temple and its surroundings of an old badger

Columbus' Audience with Isabella

Christopher Columbus proposes his plan to search for a western route to India in an audience with Spanish monarch, Isabella I. Full support is granted 3 years later, in 1489

Christian III in Veere

Danish prince and later King Christian III arrives in Veere, Zeeland

Turkish troops occupy Hungary

Council of Trent

Council of Trent resumes, overseen by Pope Julius III

Jacob van Neck's merchant fleet departs for Java, modern day Indonesia

Spanish Queirós Expedition are the first Europeans to discover Espíritu Santo, Vanuatu - although they think they have discovered Terra Australis (southern continent) [1]

Portuguese and Spanish expedition recaptures Salvador (Bahia) from the forces of the Dutch West India Company

Louis XIV and his court inaugurate the Paris Observatory

Boston Newsletter publishes 1st newspaper advertisement

Acts of Union comes into force, uniting England and Scotland to form the United Kingdom of Great Britain

Basilica of Our Lady of Guadalupe first opens its doors in Mexico City on the site of two apparitions of the Virgin - now a basilica and the holiest church in Mexico

Event of Interest

Habsburg Emperor Charles VI and Hungarian nobles including Sándor Károlyi sign Peace of Szatmar ending rebellion led by Francis II Rákóczi

Brandenburg-Prussia joins the Russian-led anti Swedish alliance by declaring war on Sweden during the Great Northern War

Spanish Catholic missionaries establish Mission San Antonio de Valero (now known as Alamo), the fist of several settlements in what is now San Antonio, Texas

Spain and Austria sign trade treaty

Species Plantarum

Publication of "Species Plantarum" by Carl Linnaeus - the formal start date of plant taxonomy adopted by the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature

France and Austria sign First Treaty of Versailles alliance - guaranteeing Austrian neutrality in war between Britain and France

Austria and France divide Prussia

British fleet occupies Guadeloupe, West Indies, capturing it from France

Cook's Chart of the St Laurence

Publication of James Cook's first significant mapping effort, "A New Chart of the River St Laurence, from the Island of Anticosti To the Falls of Richelieu." Later critical to British defeat of the French at Quebec City. [1]

Adam Weishaupt founds secret society of Illuminati

American Revolution: The Battle of Crooked Billet begins in Hatboro, Pennsylvania.

Battle of Nuʻuanu

Kamehameha I, King of Hawaiʻi defeats Kalanikupule and conquers island of Oʻahu at Battle of Nuʻuanu [approx. date]

John Phillips becomes 1st mayor of Boston

Belgian parliament accepts railway laws

Penny Black

"Penny Black", the world's first adhesive postage stamp issued by Great Britain

Whig Convention

Whig convention nominates Henry Clay as presidential candidate

Austrian explorer Ida Laura Pfeiffer (48) begins her first trip around world, leaving by boat from Hamburg bound for Rio de Janeiro

The Fraternity of Phi Gamma Delta is founded at Jefferson College in Canonsburg, Pennsylvania

John Geary becomes 1st mayor of San Francisco

First public flushing toilets the 'Monkey Closets' unveiled by George Jennings as part of The Great Exhibition at Hyde Park, London, costing one penny

1851 Great Exhibition opens in the Crystal Palace, at Hyde Park, London

Deutsches Wörterbuch

Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm publish the first part of their German Dictionary "Deutsches Wörterbuch" (fully completed 1961)

1852 The Philippine peso is introduced into circulation

Argentina adopts its constitution

Amsterdam begins transferring drinking water out of the dunes

William Walker, conqueror of Nicaragua, surrenders to US Navy

Event of Interest

General Lee orders Confederate troops under T. J. Jackson to Harper's Ferry

New Orleans Occupied

Major General Benjamin Butler's Union forces complete the occupation of New Orleans, after facing no resistance

Battle of Chancellorsville, Virginia, 29,000 injured or died

1863 Battle of Port Gibson, Mississippi

1863 Confederate "National Flag" replaces "Stars & Bars"

1863 Confederate congress passes resolution to kill black soldiers

1863 Hospital for the Ruptured and Crippled first opens its doors in New York City, oldest orthopaedic hospital in the United States

-8] Battle at Alexandria, Louisiana (Red River Campaign)

1864 Atlanta campaign in Georgia begins during US Civil War

American Equal Rights Association forms

Howard University chartered

1867 Reconstruction of South begins, black voter registration

Folies Bergère opens in Paris

1st US postal card issued

1873 Emperor Franz Joseph opens 5th World's Exposition in Vienna

238 members of "Whiskey Ring" accused of anti-US activities

1875 Alexandra Palace, London, reopens after being burnt down in 1873

Amsterdam World's Fair opens

Construction begins on Chicago's 1st skyscraper (10 stories)

1884 Proclamation of the demand for eight-hour workday in the United States.

Maria "Goeie Mie" Swanenburg sentence to life for killing 27 in Netherlands

US general strike for 8-hour working day begins

2nd International Congress calls for 1st International Workers Day 1st May 1890 to mark protests in Chicago in 1886

US Quarantine Station opens on Angel Island, San Francisco Bay

World Columbian Exposition opens in Chicago

PM Charles Tupper

Seven days after parliament was dissolved, Charles Tupper is sworn in as the 6th Prime Minister of Canada

"Fire When you are Ready"

US Admiral George Dewey commands "You may fire when you are ready, Gridley" as US rout Spanish fleet at Manila

Premature blast collapses mine tunnel killing 200 at Scofield, Utah

Pan-American Exposition opens in Buffalo, New York (runs till 2 November)

Edward VII Visits Paris

King Edward VII of Great Britain visits Paris, where he is feted in a first step toward improving Anglo-French relations, culminating in the signing of the Entente Cordiale on 8 April, 1904

Belgium government of De Trooz forms

World's most intense shower (2.47" in 3 minutes) at Portobelo, Panama

Netherlands begins unity with Belgium

The Beverly Hills Hotel opens on Sunset Boulevard in Beverly Hills, California

Longacre Theater opens at 220 W 48th St NYC

Dictator Yuan Shikai

Yuan Shikai's cabinet replaces China's provisional constitution with a constitutional compact granting the President dictatorial powers over China's military, finances, foreign policy, and the rights of Chinese citizens

Lusitania Leaves NY

British liner Lusitania leaves NY for Liverpool on its last fateful journey

1915 German submarine torpedoes US tanker Gulflight

L'Ordine Nuovo

"L'Ordine Nuovo" Italian socialist weekly newspaper established in Turin by Antonio Gramsci, Angelo Tasca and Palmiro Togliatti

Beatty Made Admiral

British naval officer David Beatty is promoted to Admiral of the Fleet

1919 Mount Kelud (Indonesia) erupts, boiling crater lake which broke through crater wall killing 5,000 people in 104 small villages

Belgium-Luxembourg toll tunnel opens

Drusian sultan Pasja al-Atrasj elected governor of Suwayda

Charlie Robertson of Chicago pitches a perfect no-hit, no-run game

Hitler, Rohn Disrupt May Day

Adolf Hitler and Ernst Rohm attempt to break up socialist May Day demonstrates, inviting Nazis from as far away as Nuremberg to take part in the violence

Admiral Paul Koundouriotis becomes President of Greece

Mercedes-Benz

German automobile manufacturers Daimler-Motoren-Gesellschaft and Benz & Cie begin their first joint venture (later merge into Mercedes-Benz)

Chinese Military Academy

Sun Yat Sen establishes the Republic of China Military Academy on Changzhou Island in Guangdong, first classes held on June 16

Cyprus becomes a British Crown Colony

British coal miners go on strike

Imperial Airways is the first British airliner to serve cooked meals

6 children die and 10 injured by hailstones in Klausenburg, Romania

1928 Drunken fascist Erich Wichman attacks VARA-radio transmitter

1928 Lei Day begins (a Hawaiian celebration)

1928 Pitcairn Airlines (later Eastern) begins service

Farm workers strike begins in East-Groningen, Netherlands

1929 Police kill 19 Mayday demonstrators in Berlin

The planet Pluto is officially named by 11-year-old English schoolgirl Venetia Burney

Empire State Building opens in New York City - world's tallest building until the World Trade Center in 1970

1931 Norway claims uninhabited Peter I Island in the Bellingshausen Sea near Antarctica

1st Suriname union congress at Paramaribo

Austria signs pact with Vatican

1934 Philippine legislature accepts US proposal for independence

1934 Water state kingdom dismisses NSB-leader Anton Mussert

Canada's 1st silver dollar is circulated

Haile Selassie Escapes

Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie leaves Ethiopia as Italy invades

Hoover Arrests Karpis

FBI's J. Edgar Hoover arrests gangster Alvin "Creepy" Karpis

Neutrality Act Signed

US President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs the Neutrality Act, banning travel on belligerent ships and imposes an arms embargo on warring nations

Pulitzer Prize awarded to Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings for "The Yearling"

140 Palestinian Jews die as German planes bomb their ship

General Mills introduces CheeriOats (renamed Cheerios in 1945) an oat-based, ready-to-eat cold cereal

1941 German assault on Tobruk

1941 US savings bonds go on sale to help finance the war effort

Radio Orange calls to defy order to wear "Jewish star"

1st edition of illegal "The Free Artist" appears in Amsterdam

1943 Food rationing begins in the United States during World War II

1943 German plane sinks the British ship SS Erinpura in the Mediterranean with the loss of 799 lives

1943 German Wehrmacht deployed in order to break Dutch strikes

1943 SS General Hanns Albin Rauter announces that all Jews will be 'removed' from the occupied Netherlands

Messerschmitt Me 262 Sturmvogel, 1st jet bomber, makes 1st flight

1944 Pulitzer prize awarded to American Martin Flavin for his novel "Journey in the Dark"

1944 Surprise attack on Weteringschans, Amsterdam, fails

About 1,000 citizens of Demmin in Germany, commit suicide provoked by occupation by Soviet Red Army

1945 Admiral Karl Doenitz forms German government

1945 Australian and Dutch troops land on Tarakan, off the coast of Borneo

1945 General Belgian Labor Union (ABVV) party forms

1945 Radio Budapest, Hungary re-enters shortwave broadcasting after WW II

1945 Seys-Inquart flees to Flensburg

1945 Soviet army reaches Rostock

Montgomery Supreme Commander

Field Marshal Bernard Montgomery appointed British supreme commander

1946 Mrs Emma Clarissa Clement named "American Mother of Year" by the American Mothers Committee of the Golden Rule Foundation in New York

1946 Start of the three-year Pilbara strike by indigenous Aboriginals in Western Australia for better wages and conditions [1]

1946 The Paris Peace Conference concludes that the islands of the Dodecanese should be returned to Greece by Italy

General Hoyt Vandenberg, ends his term as the second head of the CIA

1947 Radar for commercial & private planes 1st demonstrated

1947 Rear Admiral Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, becomes the third Director of the CIA

Glenn Taylor, Idaho Senator, arrested in Birmingham, Alabama, for trying to enter a meeting through a door marked "for Negroes"

1948 North Korea proclaims itself Democratic People's Republic of Korea

Auspicia Quaedam

Pope Pius XII publishes encyclical Auspicia quaedam

Gerard Kuiper discovers Nereid, (2nd satellite of Neptune)

Gwendolyn Brooks is the first African American awarded the Pulitzer Prize for poetry for "Annie Allen"

1950 Mayor of Brussels reluctantly bans May Day parade

1950 New marriage laws enforced in People's Republic of China

600,000 march for peace & freedom in Germany

1951 Dutch Reformed Church introduces new church choir

Mr Potato Head first introduced by toy distributor Hasbro

1952 TWA introduces tourist class

1952 US Marines take part in an atomic explosion training in Nevada

Bishops publish Mandement (member socialist org forbidden)

1954 HSA-UWC Forms (Unification Church) (Moonies)

1954 The Hudson Motor Car Company merges with the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation to form the American Motors Corporation [1]

Miss Atomic Pageant

Showgirl Linda Lawson is crowned "Miss-Cue" in the Atomic Pageant, after the Operation Cue test is repeatedly delayed by high winds

A doctor in Japan reports an "epidemic of an unknown disease of the central nervous system", marking the official discovery of Minamata disease

US gives Poland credit of $95 million

1957 Vanguard TV-1 booster test reaches 195 km

Ambonese rebellion bombs Ambon, conquers Morotai

1958 Arturo Frondizi sworn in as President of Argentina

West Germany introduces a 5-day work week

India's Bombay state split into Gujarat & Maharashtra states

Event of Interest

Russia shoots down Francis Gary Powers' U-2 spy plane over Sverdlovsk

1st US airplane hijacked to Cuba

Event of Interest

Fidel Castro announces there will be no more elections in Cuba

Event of Interest

Pulitzer prize awarded to Harper Lee for her novel "To Kill a Mockingbird"

1961 Tanganyika granted full internal self-government by Britain

1st French underground nuclear test in the Sahara at Ecker, Algeria

Event of Interest

JFK authorizes Area Redevelopment Act (ARA)

1st American (James Whittaker) conquers Mount Everest

A Bunny's Tale

Gloria Steinem's exposé, "A Bunny's Tale", on the working conditions for waitresses (bunnies) at New York City’s famed Playboy Club, published in "Show" magazine

1963 Indonesia takes control of Irian Jaya (west New Guinea) from the Netherlands

1st BASIC program runs on a computer (Dartmouth)

Battle of Dong-Yin, a naval conflict between ROC and PRC, takes place.

1965 USSR launches Luna 5; later impacts on Moon

Radio RSA, South Africa begins shortwave transmitting

1966 US troops shooting targets in Cambodia

Event of Interest

Anastasio Somoza Debayle becomes President of Nicaragua

1967 Jelle Zijlstra becomes president of Netherlands Bank

1967 Pulitzer Prize awarded to Bernard Malamud (Fixer)

43 Unification church couples wed in NYC

1969 Pirate Radio Station 259 (England/France) begins transmitting

Amtrak Railroad begins operation

North Vietnamese troops occupy Quang Tri Activities Committee

1972 Pulitzer prize awarded to Wallace Stegner for his novel Angle of Repose

1972 Radio's Mutual Black Network premieres

36 people are killed in Taksim Square, Istanbul, during the Labour Day celebrations.

1st African American mayor of New Orleans, Ernest Nathan Morial, inaugurated

1978 Naomi Uemura became 1st to reach North Pole overland alone

Home rule introduced to Kalaallit Nunaat (Greenland)

1979 Marshall Islands (in Pacific) become self-governing

Amer Book Award: William Styron (Sophie Choice)/T Wolfe (Right Stuff)

Harrison Williams (Sen-D-NJ) convicted on FBI Abscam charges

1981 Radio Shack releases Model III TRSDOS 1.3

1982 World's Fair in Knoxville Tennessee opens

1984 Great Britain performs nuclear test at Nevada Test Site

"Communist" bomb attack kills 2 firemen in Brussels

Event of Interest

US President Reagan ends embargo against Nicaragua

Previous

1

2

Next
